perturbation.original_text: A Party will have ten (10) days to provide adequate assurances of performance to the other Party in a form acceptable to the other Party in its good faith discretion.
perturbation.changed_text: A Party will have two (2) days to provide adequate assurances of performance to the other Party in a form acceptable to the other Party in its good faith discretion.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the time to provide adequate assurance of performance could be considered commercially unreasonable and may not provide sufficient time for a party to gather the necessary documentation. This contradicts the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing present in all contracts, as codified in the UCC.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Uniform Commercial Code - Adequate Assurance of Performance
perturbation.law_explanation: UCC ยง 2-609 allows a party, when reasonable grounds for insecurity arise, to demand adequate assurance of due performance and, until the party receives such assurance, to suspend its performance. Giving only two days might not be considered a reasonable time to respond, violating the spirit of good faith required under the UCC.

perturbation.original_text: An insuring Party must deliver the following written evidence of the required insurance coverage to the other Party (Attention: Risk Management), or its designated insurance monitoring service, within ten (10) of written request and at least thirty (30) days in advance of the expiration of a then current policy term (if a declaration or endorsement is not available from an insurer at the time requested or required, an insuring Party will provide them as soon as the declaration or endorsement is available from the insurer):
perturbation.changed_text: An insuring Party must deliver the following written evidence of the required insurance coverage to the other Party (Attention: Risk Management), or its designated insurance monitoring service, within two (2) of written request and at least five (5) days in advance of the expiration of a then current policy term (if a declaration or endorsement is not available from an insurer at the time requested or required, an insuring Party will provide them as soon as the declaration or endorsement is available from the insurer):
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the time to provide proof of insurance and advance notice before expiration could be considered commercially unreasonable given the difficulties sometimes inherent in obtaining documentation from insurance companies. This contradicts the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Duty of Good Faith and Fair Dealing
perturbation.law_explanation: Illinois law implies a covenant of good faith and fair dealing in every contract. The implied covenant requires contracting parties to act reasonably and honestly when exercising their contractual discretion. Shortening the timeframe to 2 days for insurance documents and 5 days before policy expiration may be seen as not providing enough time and acting not in good faith.

perturbation.original_text: A Receiving Party will return or destroy all forms of Confidential Information of the Disclosing Party in the custody of the Receiving Party and its Representatives within ten (10) days of receipt of a written request from the Disclosing Party and after the expiration or earlier termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: A Receiving Party will return or destroy all forms of Confidential Information of the Disclosing Party in the custody of the Receiving Party and its Representatives within one hundred eighty (180) days of receipt of a written request from the Disclosing Party and after the expiration or earlier termination of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the time to return or destroy confidential information to 180 days could potentially violate trade secret laws if such a delay creates an unreasonable risk of disclosure or misuse of the confidential information, particularly if the information is highly sensitive.
perturbation.law_explanation: The Illinois Trade Secrets Act (765 ILCS 1065/) defines a trade secret and provides remedies for misappropriation. Allowing a Receiving Party 180 days to return or destroy confidential information could create a situation where misappropriation is more likely, and depending on the sensitivity of the trade secret, create unnecessary risk for the disclosing party.
